name: Vitamin D (Cholecalciferol, Ergocalciferol)
summary: Vitamin D is a fat-soluble vitamin essential for calcium and phosphate homeostasis, bone health, and immune function. Its main forms are D2 (ergocalciferol, plant-derived) and D3 (cholecalciferol, synthesized in skin or from animal sources).
description: Vitamin D plays a critical role in calcium absorption, bone mineralization, and maintaining serum calcium and phosphorus levels. It also influences muscle function, immune regulation, and cell differentiation. Vitamin D can be obtained from sunlight exposure, diet, or supplements. Deficiency is common and can cause rickets in children, osteomalacia in adults, and contribute to osteoporosis. Supplementation is used to prevent and treat deficiency, with emerging research on roles in immunity, cardiovascular health, mood disorders, and cancer prevention.

metadata.natural_source: Sunlight (UVB-induced skin synthesis), fatty fish, egg yolk, fortified dairy and cereals
metadata.prescription_status: OTC (low dose), prescription (high dose or injectable)

primary_indications: Prevention and treatment of vitamin D deficiency
off_label_uses: Fall and fracture prevention in elderly
Possible role in cancer prevention (under investigation)
contraindications: Granulomatous disorders (e.g., sarcoidosis) with risk of excessive vitamin D activation

items: Prevention and treatment of vitamin D deficiency
Adjunctive therapy in osteoporosis and fracture prevention

sections.text: Vitamin D (D2 and D3) is converted in the liver to 25-hydroxyvitamin D (calcidiol), then in the kidney to its active form 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D (calcitriol). Calcitriol binds to vitamin D receptors (VDRs), regulating gene transcription related to calcium and phosphate absorption, bone remodeling, and immune modulation.

adult.deficiency treatment: 50,000 IU weekly for 6–8 weeks, then maintenance

sections.pediatric: 400–600 IU/day depending on age; higher doses for deficiency under supervision

sections.text: Correction of deficiency may take weeks; skeletal improvements may take months. Maintenance requires continued intake.

common: Generally well tolerated at recommended doses

other: Risk of hypercalcemia with excessive doses or in patients with granulomatous disease.
Use with caution in renal insufficiency.

sections.pregnancy: Safe at recommended doses; avoid excessive intake
sections.lactation: Safe; supplementation may be necessary for mother and infant
sections.geriatrics: Safe; may require higher doses due to reduced skin synthesis

sections.text: Not required, but long-term discontinuation may lead to recurrent deficiency.

items: Vitamin D deficiency is highly prevalent worldwide, especially in older adults and people with limited sun exposure.
Vitamin D3 (cholecalciferol) is generally more effective than D2 (ergocalciferol) at raising serum 25(OH)D levels.
High-dose intermittent regimens (e.g., 50,000 IU weekly) are common for deficiency correction, followed by maintenance dosing.
Over-supplementation can cause serious toxicity through hypercalcemia.
